Utilities for data manipulation

Tiago Olivoto

2019-12-22

Source: vignettes/vignettes_utilities.Rmd
vignettes_utilities.Rmd

Utilities for rows and columns

Add columns and rows

The functions add_cols() and add_rows() can be used to add columns and rows, respectively to a data frame.

library(metan)
Registered S3 method overwritten by 'GGally':
  method from   
  +.gg   ggplot2

********************************************************
metan has been successfully loaded in R 3.6.1
Please, see the complete vignette at:
https://tiagoolivoto.github.io/metan/
Suppress this message with: suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(metan))
********************************************************
add_columns(data_ge,
            ROW_ID = seq(1:nrow(data_ge)))
# A tibble: 420 x 6
   ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM ROW_ID
   <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>  <int>
 1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9      1
 2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9      2
 3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8      3
 4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2      4
 5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3      5
 6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5      6
 7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7      7
 8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2      8
 9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8      9
10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9     10
# … with 410 more rows
add_columns(data_ge,
            ROW_ID = seq(1:nrow(data_ge)),
            before = "GEN")
# A tibble: 420 x 6
   ENV   ROW_ID GEN   REP      GY    HM
   <fct>  <int> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 E1         1 G1    1      2.17  44.9
 2 E1         2 G1    2      2.50  46.9
 3 E1         3 G1    3      2.43  47.8
 4 E1         4 G2    1      3.21  45.2
 5 E1         5 G2    2      2.93  45.3
 6 E1         6 G2    3      2.56  45.5
 7 E1         7 G3    1      2.77  46.7
 8 E1         8 G3    2      3.62  43.2
 9 E1         9 G3    3      2.28  47.8
10 E1        10 G4    1      2.36  47.9
# … with 410 more rows

  select(union_var("C", "D"))

Concatenating columns

The function concatetate() can be used to concatenate either two columns of a data frame or a column and specified values. Return a data frame with all the original columns in .data plus the concatenated variable, after the last column.

concatenate(data_ge, ENV, GEN)
# A tibble: 420 x 6
   ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM new_var
   <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  
 1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_G1  
 2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_G1  
 3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_G1  
 4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_G2  
 5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_G2  
 6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_G2  
 7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_G3  
 8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_G3  
 9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_G3  
10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_G4  
# … with 410 more rows

If only one column is in the data, col_1 or col_2 must be a numeric or a character vector of length equals to the number of rows in data. Vectors of length 1 will be recycled.

concatenate(data_ge, ENV, rep(1:14, each=30))
# A tibble: 420 x 6
   ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM new_var
   <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  
 1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_1   
 2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_1   
 3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_1   
 4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_1   
 5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_1   
 6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_1   
 7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_1   
 8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_1   
 9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_1   
10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_1   
# … with 410 more rows

Other functions can be used to provide such vector. Here, we will replace the string “G” from genotype colum with “GEN” and concatenate this column with “ENV”. Note that the argument pull into the function replace_string() is used to pull out the result of the replacing function.

conc_data <- 
concatenate(data_ge,
            col_1 = ENV,
            col_2 = replace_string(data_ge,
                                   GEN,
                                   replacement = "GEN_",
                                   pull = TRUE),
            new_var = ENV_GEN)
conc_data
# A tibble: 420 x 6
   ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM ENV_GEN 
   <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   
 1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_GEN_1
 2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_GEN_1
 3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_GEN_1
 4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_GEN_2
 5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_GEN_2
 6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_GEN_2
 7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_GEN_3
 8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_GEN_3
 9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_GEN_3
10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_GEN_4
# … with 410 more rows

To check if a column exists in a data frame, use column_exists()

column_exists(conc_data, "ENV_GEN")
[1] TRUE

To get the levels and the size of the levels of a factor, the functions get_levels() and get_level_size() can be used.

get_levels(conc_data, ENV)
 [1] "E1"  "E10" "E11" "E12" "E13" "E14" "E2"  "E3"  "E4"  "E5"  "E6"  "E7" 
[13] "E8"  "E9" 
get_level_size(conc_data, ENV)
 E1 E10 E11 E12 E13 E14  E2  E3  E4  E5  E6  E7  E8  E9 
 30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30  30

Selecting numeric and non-numeric columns

Numeric columns can be selected quickly by using the function select_numeric_cols(). Non-numeric columns are selected with select_non_numeric_cols()

select_numeric_cols(data_ge)
# A tibble: 420 x 2
      GY    HM
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  2.17  44.9
 2  2.50  46.9
 3  2.43  47.8
 4  3.21  45.2
 5  2.93  45.3
 6  2.56  45.5
 7  2.77  46.7
 8  3.62  43.2
 9  2.28  47.8
10  2.36  47.9
# … with 410 more rows
select_non_numeric_cols(data_ge)
# A tibble: 420 x 3
   ENV   GEN   REP  
   <fct> <fct> <fct>
 1 E1    G1    1    
 2 E1    G1    2    
 3 E1    G1    3    
 4 E1    G2    1    
 5 E1    G2    2    
 6 E1    G2    3    
 7 E1    G3    1    
 8 E1    G3    2    
 9 E1    G3    3    
10 E1    G4    1    
# … with 410 more rows
